description: Learn how to make your website interactive by responding to user actions like clicks, keypresses, and form submissions.

slides.title: What are Events?
slides.content:
# Events ğŸ””

HTML events are "things" that happen to HTML elements.

When JS is used in HTML pages, JS can "react" on these events.

Examples:
- An HTML button was clicked
- The page has finished loading
- An input field was changed

slides.title: Onclick Event
slides.content:
# The onclick Event ğŸ–±ï¸

Execute code when an element is clicked.

```html
<button onclick="alert('Hello!')">Click Me</button>
```

Or using JS function:

```html
<button onclick="myFunction()">Click Me</button>
<script>
function myFunction() {
  alert("Button clicked!");
}
</script>
```

slides.title: Common Mouse Events
slides.content:
# Mouse Events ğŸ­ - `onclick`: The user clicks an HTML element. - `onmouseover`: The user moves the mouse over an element. - `onmouseout`: The user moves the mouse away from an element. - `onmousedown`: The user presses a mouse button over an element. ```html
Hover over me!
```

slides.title: Keyboard Events
Form Events
slides.content:
# Form Events ğŸ“

- `onchange`: An HTML element has been changed (e.g., input, select).
- `onsubmit`: The form is submitted.
- `onfocus`: An element gets focus.
- `onblur`: An element loses focus.

```html
<input type="text" onchange="upperCase()">
```
